</td>

      <tr>
        <td id="L151" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="151"></td>
        <td id="LC151" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">To illustrate our workflow, we analyzed two types of brain</td>

</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>

        <td id="LC159" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-mh"><span class="pl-mh">#</span><span class="pl-mh"> </span>Introduction</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L160" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="160"></td>
        <td id="LC160" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L161" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="161"></td>
        <td id="LC161" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Cancer is a complex genetic disease spanning multiple molecular events</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L162" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="162"></td>
        <td id="LC162" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">such as point mutations, structural variations, translocations and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L163" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="163"></td>
        <td id="LC163" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">activation of epigenetic and transcriptional signatures and networks.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L164" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="164"></td>
        <td id="LC164" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">The effects of these events take place at different spatial and temporal</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L165" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="165"></td>
        <td id="LC165" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">scales with interlayer communications and feedback mechanisms creating a</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L166" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="166"></td>
        <td id="LC166" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">highly complex dynamic system. To gain insight into the biology of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L167" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="167"></td>
        <td id="LC167" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">tumors most of the research in cancer genomics is aimed at the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L168" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="168"></td>
        <td id="LC168" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">integration of the observations at multiple molecular scales and the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L169" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="169"></td>
        <td id="LC169" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">analysis of their interplay. Even if many tumors share similar recurrent</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L170" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="170"></td>
        <td id="LC170" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">genomic events, their relationships with the observed phenotype are</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L171" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="171"></td>
        <td id="LC171" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">often not understood. For example, although we know that the majority of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L172" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="172"></td>
        <td id="LC172" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">the most aggressive form of brain tumors such as glioma harbor the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L173" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="173"></td>
        <td id="LC173" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">mutation of a single gene (IDH), the mechanistic explanation of the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L174" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="174"></td>
        <td id="LC174" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">activation of its characteristic epigenetic and transcriptional</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L175" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="175"></td>
        <td id="LC175" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">signatures are still far to be well characterized. Moreover,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L176" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="176"></td>
        <td id="LC176" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">network-based strategies have recently emerged as an effective framework</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L177" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="177"></td>
        <td id="LC177" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">for the discovery functional disease drivers that act as main regulators</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L178" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="178"></td>
        <td id="LC178" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">of cancer phenotypes. Here we describe a comprehensive workflow that</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L179" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="179"></td>
        <td id="LC179" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">integrates many Bioconductor packages in order to analyze and integrate</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L180" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="180"></td>
        <td id="LC180" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">the multiplicity of molecular observation layers in large-scale cancer</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L181" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="181"></td>
        <td id="LC181" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">dataset.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L182" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="182"></td>
        <td id="LC182" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L183" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="183"></td>
        <td id="LC183" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Indeed, recent technological developments allowed the deposition of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L184" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="184"></td>
        <td id="LC184" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">large amounts of genomic and epigenomic data, such as gene expression,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L185" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="185"></td>
        <td id="LC185" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">DNA methylation, and genomic localization of transcription factors, into</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L186" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="186"></td>
        <td id="LC186" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">freely available public international consortia like The Cancer Genome</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L187" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="187"></td>
        <td id="LC187" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Atlas ([<span class="pl-e">TCGA</span>](http://cancergenome.nih.gov/)), The Encyclopedia of DNA</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L188" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="188"></td>
        <td id="LC188" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Elements ([<span class="pl-e">ENCODE</span>](http://www.encodeproject.org/)), and The NIH Roadmap</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L189" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="189"></td>
        <td id="LC189" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Epigenomics Mapping Consortium</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L190" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="190"></td>
        <td id="LC190" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">([<span class="pl-e">Roadmap</span>](http://www.roadmapepigenomics.org/)) [<span class="pl-v">@</span><span class="pl-s">Hawkins</span>]. An overview</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L191" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="191"></td>

      <tr>
        <td id="L664" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="664"></td>

        <td id="LC666" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">result of genomic rearrangements, such as deletions, duplications,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>

</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L671" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="671"></td>
        <td id="LC671" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">TCGA collects copy number data and allows the CNV profiling of cancer.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L672" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="672"></td>
        <td id="LC672" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Tumor and paired-normal DNA samples were analyzed for CNV detection</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L673" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="673"></td>
        <td id="LC673" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">using microarray- and sequencing-based technologies. Level 3 processed</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>

      <tr>

      <tr>
        <td id="L710" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="710"></td>
        <td id="LC710" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-mh"><span class="pl-mh">###</span><span class="pl-mh"> </span>Identification of recurrent CNV in cancer</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L711" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="711"></td>
        <td id="LC711" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Cancer-related CNV has to be present in many of the analyzed genomes.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L712" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="712"></td>
        <td id="LC712" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">The most significant recurrent CNV were identified using</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L713" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="713"></td>
        <td id="LC713" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">[<span class="pl-e">GAIA</span>](http://bioconductor.org/packages/gaia/) [<span class="pl-v">@</span><span class="pl-s">morganellagaia</span>], an</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L714" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="714"></td>
        <td id="LC714" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">iterative procedure where a statistical hypothesis framework is extended</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L715" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="715"></td>
        <td id="LC715" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">to take into account within-sample homogeneity. GAIA is based on a</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L716" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="716"></td>
        <td id="LC716" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">conservative permutation test allowing the estimation of the probability</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L717" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="717"></td>
        <td id="LC717" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">distribution of the contemporary mutations expected for non-driver</td>
      </tr>

In</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1765" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1765"></td>
        <td id="LC1765" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">this section, we will introduce a Bioconductor package called</td>

        <td id="LC1766" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">[<span class="pl-e">ELMER</span>](http://bioconductor.org/packages/ELMER/) to identify regulatory</td>

      <tr>
        <td id="L1767" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1767"></td>

      <tr>

      <tr>
        <td id="L1775" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1775"></td>
        <td id="LC1775" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">After finding differentially methylated CpG sites, one might ask whether</td>

        <td id="LC1777" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">decrease. DNA methylation at promoters of genes has been shown to be</td>

        <td id="L1778" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1778"></td>
        <td id="LC1778" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">associated with silencing of the respective gene. The starburst plot is</td>

        <td id="LC1780" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">for studies of DNA methylation and gene expression</td>

      <tr>

        <td id="LC1788" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">horizontal black dashed line shows the FDR-adjusted p-value of $10^{-2}$</td>

      <tr>

        <td id="L2006" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2006"></td>
        <td id="LC2006" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">The hypomethylated and hypermethylated regions are enriched for H3K4me3,</td>

        <td id="L2008" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2008"></td>

      <tr>

        <td id="LC2010" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">repression as the H3K36me3 and H3K27me3 heatmaps do not show an</td>

        <td id="L2011" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2011"></td>

</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2016" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2016"></td>
        <td id="LC2016" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Recently, many studies suggest that enhancers play a major role as</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2017" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2017"></td>
        <td id="LC2017" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">regulators of cell-specific phenotypes leading to alteration in</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2018" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2018"></td>
        <td id="LC2018" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">transcriptomes related to diseases</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2019" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2019"></td>
        <td id="LC2019" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">[<span class="pl-v">@</span><span class="pl-s">giorgio2015large</span>; <span class="pl-v">@</span><span class="pl-s">groschel2014single</span>; <span class="pl-v">@</span><span class="pl-s">sur2012mice</span>; <span class="pl-v">@</span><span class="pl-s">yao2015demystifying</span>].</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2020" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2020"></td>
        <td id="LC2020" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">In order to investigate regulatory enhancers that can be located at long</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2021" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2021"></td>
        <td id="LC2021" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">distances upstream or downstream of target genes Bioconductor offer the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2022" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2022"></td>
        <td id="LC2022" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">[Enhancer Linking by Methylation/Expression Relationship</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2023" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2023"></td>
        <td id="LC2023" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">(ELMER)](http://bioconductor.org/packages/ELMER/) package. This package</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2024" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2024"></td>
        <td id="LC2024" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">is designed to combine DNA methylation and gene expression data from</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2025" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2025"></td>
        <td id="LC2025" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">human tissues to infer multi-level cis-regulatory networks. It uses DNA</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2026" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2026"></td>
        <td id="LC2026" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">methylation to identify enhancers and correlates their state with</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>

</td>

      <tr>
        <td id="L2053" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2053"></td>
        <td id="LC2053" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">The listing below shows how to use</td>

      <tr>

        <td id="LC2054" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">[<span class="pl-e">TCGAbiolinks</span>](http://bioconductor.org/packages/TCGAbiolinks/)</td>

      <tr>

      <tr>
        <td id="L2062" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2062"></td>
        <td id="LC2062" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">To perform ELMER analyses, we need to populate a <span class="pl-mb">**MultiAssayExperiment**</span> with a DNA methylation matrix or <span class="pl-mb">**SummarizedExperiment**</span> object from HM450K or EPIC platform; a gene expression matrix or SummarizedExperiment object for the same samples; a matrix mapping DNA methylation samples to gene expression samples; and a matrix with sample metadata (i.e. clinical data, molecular subtype, etc.). If TCGA data are used, the last two matrices will be automatically generated.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2063" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2063"></td>
        <td id="LC2063" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">If using non-TCGA data,  the matrix with sample metadata should be provided with at least a column with a patient identifier and another one identifying its group which will be used for analysis, if samples in the methylation and expression matrices are not ordered and with same names, a matrix mapping for each patient identifier their DNA methylation samples and their gene expression samples should be provided to the <span class="pl-mi">*createMAE*</span> function.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2064" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2064"></td>
        <td id="LC2064" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Based on the genome of reference selected, metadata for the DNA methylation probes, such as genomic coordinates, will be added from http://zwdzwd.github.io/InfiniumAnnotation [<span class="pl-v">@</span><span class="pl-s">zhou2016comprehensive</span>]; </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2065" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2065"></td>
        <td id="LC2065" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">and metadata for gene expression and annotation is added from Ensembl database [<span class="pl-v">@</span><span class="pl-s">yates2015ensembl</span>] using [<span class="pl-e">biomaRt</span>](http://bioconductor.org/packages/biomaRt/) [<span class="pl-v">@</span><span class="pl-s">durinck2009mapping</span>]. </td>
      </tr>

        <td id="L2151" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2151"></td>
        <td id="LC2151" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-mh"><span class="pl-mh">###</span><span class="pl-mh"> </span>Supervised and unsupervised analysis mode</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2152" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2152"></td>
        <td id="LC2152" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2153" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2153"></td>

</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2154" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2154"></td>
        <td id="LC2154" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">ELMER is designed to identify differences between two sets of samples within a given dataset. But, before we start our analysis, it is better to understand the two analysis mode available in ELMER 2.0 (supervised and unsupervised mode) which affects how the samples are selected for each comparison.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2155" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2155"></td>
        <td id="LC2155" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2156" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2156"></td>
        <td id="LC2156" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"> In original version  [<span class="pl-v">@</span><span class="pl-s">yao2015inferring</span>], the first step - identification of differentially methylated CpG probes (DMCs) - was hard-coded to identify DMCs between non-cancer vs. cancer samples, and the subsequent step was unsupervised, identifying changes within any subset of tumors. In ELMER 2.0, we generalize these strategies so that they are applicable to any paired dataset, including disease vs. healthy tissue for any disease type. </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2157" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2157"></td>
        <td id="LC2157" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"> </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2158" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2158"></td>
        <td id="LC2158" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">In the Unsupervised mode, as in ELMER 1.0, it is assumed that at least one of our groups is heterogenous (i.e Breast Invasive Carcinoma primary solid tumors samples might belong to basal,Luminal A, Her2 molecular subtypes), for that reason  for each comparison samples from two most extreme quintiles based on DNA methylation levels were used, generating both the $M$ (methylated) and the $U$ (unmethylated) groups. In the Supervised mode, it is assumed that our groups are homogenous, for that reason the $U$ and $M$ groups are defined strictly by sample group labels, and all samples in each group are used [<span class="pl-v">@</span><span class="pl-s">ChedraouiSilva148726</span>].</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2159" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2159"></td>
        <td id="LC2159" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2160" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2160"></td>
        <td id="LC2160" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">The next steps we will perform ELMER analysis using the supervised mode, which will use all samples from GBM and compare to all LGG samples in all analysis.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2161" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2161"></td>
        <td id="LC2161" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2162" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2162"></td>
        <td id="LC2162" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-mh"><span class="pl-mh">###</span><span class="pl-mh"> </span>Identification of differentially methylated CpGs (DMCs)</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2163" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2163"></td>
        <td id="LC2163" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2164" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2164"></td>
        <td id="LC2164" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">For each distal probe, samples of each group (group 1 and group 2) are ranked by their DNA methylation beta values, those samples in the lower quintile (20\% samples with the lowest methylation levels) of each group are used to identify if the probe is hypomethylated in group 1 compared to group 2, using an unpaired one-tailed t-test. The 20\% is a parameter to the *diff.meth* function called *minSubgroupFrac*. For the (ungrouped) cancer case, this is set to 20\% as in [@yao2015inferring], because we typically wanted to be able to detect a specific molecular subtype among the tumor samples; these subtypes often make up only a minority of samples, and 20\% was chosen as a lower bound for the purposes of statistical power (high enough sample numbers to yield t-test p-values that could overcome multiple hypothesis corrections, yet low enough to be able to capture changes in individual molecular subtypes occurring in 20\% or more of the cases.) This number can be set arbitrarily as an input to the *diff.meth* function and should be tuned based on sample sizes in individual studies. </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2165" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2165"></td>
        <td id="LC2165" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2166" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2166"></td>
        <td id="LC2166" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">As we are dealing with a low number of samples, and we are comparing two cancer types the <span class="pl-mi">*minSubgroupFrac*</span> parameter is set to 100<span class="pl-cce">\%</span> to use all samples in this analysis. </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>

      <tr>
        <td id="L2192" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2192"></td>

</td>

      <tr>
        <td id="L2193" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2193"></td>
        <td id="LC2193" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-mh"><span class="pl-mh">###</span><span class="pl-mh"> </span>Identification of putative target gene(s) for differentially methylated distal probes</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2194" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2194"></td>
        <td id="LC2194" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2195" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2195"></td>
        <td id="LC2195" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">For each differentially methylated distal probe (DMC), the closest 10 upstream </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2196" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2196"></td>
        <td id="LC2196" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">genes and the closest 10 downstream genes are tested for inverse correlation between </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2197" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2197"></td>
        <td id="LC2197" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">methylation of the probe and expression of the gene (the number 10 can be changed using the <span class="pl-mi">*numFlankingGenes*</span> parameter). To select these genes, the probe-gene distance is defined as the distance from the probe to the transcription </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2198" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2198"></td>
        <td id="LC2198" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">start site specified by the ENSEMBL gene level annotations [<span class="pl-v">@</span><span class="pl-s">yates2015ensembl</span>] accessed via</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2199" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2199"></td>
        <td id="LC2199" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">the R/Bioconductor package [<span class="pl-e">biomaRt</span>](http://bioconductor.org/packages/biomaRt/) [<span class="pl-v">@</span><span class="pl-s">durinck2009mapping</span>,@durinck2005biomart]. By choosing a constant number of genes to test for each probe, our goal is to avoid systematic false positives for probes in gene-rich regions. This is especially important given the highly non-uniform gene density of mammalian genomes.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2200" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2200"></td>
        <td id="LC2200" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Thus, exactly 20 statistical tests were performed for each probe, as follows. </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2201" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2201"></td>
        <td id="LC2201" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2202" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2202"></td>
        <td id="LC2202" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">For each probe-gene pair, the samples (all samples from both groups) are divided into two </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2203" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2203"></td>
        <td id="LC2203" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">groups: the M group, which consisted of the upper methylation quintile (the 20<span class="pl-cce">\%</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2204" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2204"></td>
        <td id="LC2204" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">of samples with the highest methylation at the enhancer probe), and the U group, </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2205" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2205"></td>
        <td id="LC2205" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">which consists of the lowest methylation quintile (the 20<span class="pl-cce">\%</span> of samples with the </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2206" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2206"></td>
        <td id="LC2206" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">lowest methylation.) The 20<span class="pl-cce">\%</span> ile cutoff is a configurable parameter <span class="pl-mi">*minSubgroupFrac*</span> in the <span class="pl-mi">*get.pair*</span> function.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2207" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2207"></td>
        <td id="LC2207" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">As with its usage in the <span class="pl-mi">*diff.meth*</span> function, the default value of 20<span class="pl-cce">\%</span> is a balance, allowing for the identification of changes in a  molecular subtype making up a minority (i.e. 20<span class="pl-cce">\%</span>) of cases, while also yielding </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2208" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2208"></td>
        <td id="LC2208" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">enough statistical power to make strong predictions. For larger sample sizes or other experimental designs, this could be set even lower.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2209" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2209"></td>
        <td id="LC2209" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2210" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2210"></td>
        <td id="LC2210" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">For each candidate probe-gene pair, </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2211" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2211"></td>
        <td id="LC2211" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">the Mann-Whitney U test is used to test the null hypothesis that overall gene </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2212" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2212"></td>
        <td id="LC2212" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">expression in group M is greater than or equal than that in group U. </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2213" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2213"></td>
        <td id="LC2213" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">This non-parametric test was used in order to minimize the effects </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2214" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2214"></td>
        <td id="LC2214" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">of expression outliers, which can  occur across a very wide dynamic range. </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2215" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2215"></td>
        <td id="LC2215" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">For each probe-gene pair tested, the raw p-value $P_r$ is corrected for multiple </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2216" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2216"></td>
        <td id="LC2216" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">hypothesis using a permutation approach as follows.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2217" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2217"></td>
        <td id="LC2217" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">The gene in the pair is held constant, and <span class="pl-mi">*x*</span> random methylation probes are </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2218" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2218"></td>
        <td id="LC2218" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">chosen to perform the same one-tailed U test, generating a set of <span class="pl-mi">*x*</span> permutation</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2219" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2219"></td>
        <td id="LC2219" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">p-values $P_p$. We chose the x random probes only from among those that were </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2220" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2220"></td>
        <td id="LC2220" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">&quot;distal&quot; (farther than $2kb$ from an annotated transcription start site), in order </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2221" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2221"></td>
        <td id="LC2221" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">to draw these null-model probes from the same set as the probe being tested [<span class="pl-v">@</span><span class="pl-s">sham2014statistical</span>]. </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2222" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2222"></td>
        <td id="LC2222" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">An empirical p-value $P_e$ value was calculated using the following formula </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2223" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2223"></td>
        <td id="LC2223" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">(which introduces a pseudo-count of 1):</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2224" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2224"></td>
        <td id="LC2224" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2225" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2225"></td>
        <td id="LC2225" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-cce">\b</span>egin{equation}</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2226" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2226"></td>
        <td id="LC2226" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">P_e = <span class="pl-cce">\f</span>rac{num(P_p <span class="pl-cce">\l</span>eq P_r)+ 1}{x+1}</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2227" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2227"></td>
        <td id="LC2227" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-cce">\e</span>nd{equation}</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2228" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2228"></td>
        <td id="LC2228" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2229" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2229"></td>
        <td id="LC2229" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Notice that in the <span class="pl-mi">*Supervised*</span> mode, no additional filtering is necessary to ensure that the M and U group segregate by sample group labels.  The two sample groups are segregated by definition, since these probes were selected for their differential methylation, with the same directionality, between the two groups. </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2230" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2230"></td>
        <td id="LC2230" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"> </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2231" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2231"></td>
        <td id="LC2231" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">In our example, we will reduce the number of closest genes evaluated to 5 (the 2 closest upstream </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2232" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2232"></td>
        <td id="LC2232" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">genes and the closest 2 downstream genes). The <span class="pl-mi">*mode*</span> is set to &quot;supervised&quot; which will set group 1 (GBM samples) as the $U$ group, and the group 2 (LGG samples) as $M$ group.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2233" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2233"></td>
        <td id="LC2233" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Also, to make the example faster, the number of permutation is reduced to 5 (<span class="pl-mi">*permu.size*</span> = 5), the raw p-value cut-off is loosened to 0.1 and the empirical p-value to 0.5, but it is recommended in a real analysis to use the default values.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2234" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2234"></td>
        <td id="LC2234" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2235" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2235"></td>
        <td id="LC2235" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c1">```{r, warning=FALSE, results=&quot;hide&quot;} </span><span class="pl-s1"></span></td>
      </tr>

      <tr>
        <td id="L2309" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2309"></td>
        <td id="LC2309" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-mh"><span class="pl-mh">###</span><span class="pl-mh"> </span>Identification of master regulator TFs</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2310" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2310"></td>
        <td id="LC2310" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2311" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2311"></td>
        <td id="LC2311" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2312" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2312"></td>
        <td id="LC2312" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2313" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2313"></td>
        <td id="LC2313" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">When a group of enhancers is coordinately altered in a specific sample subset, this is often the result of an altered upstream <span class="pl-mi">*master regulator*</span> transcription factor in the gene regulatory network. <span class="pl-mi">*ELMER*</span> tries to identify such transcription factors corresponding to each of the TF binding motifs enriched from the previous analysis step.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2314" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2314"></td>
        <td id="LC2314" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">For each enriched motif, <span class="pl-mi">*ELMER*</span> takes the average DNA methylation of all distal probes (in significant probe-gene pairs) that contain that motif occurrence (within a $<span class="pl-cce">\p</span>m 250bp$ region) and compares this average DNA methylation to the expression of each gene annotated as a human TF.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2315" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2315"></td>
        <td id="LC2315" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2316" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2316"></td>
        <td id="LC2316" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2317" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2317"></td>
        <td id="LC2317" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">In the Unsupervised mode, a statistical test is performed for each motif-TF pair, as follows. All samples </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2318" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2318"></td>
        <td id="LC2318" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">are divided into two groups: the $M$ group, which consists </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2319" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2319"></td>
        <td id="LC2319" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">of the 20<span class="pl-cce">\%</span> of samples with the highest average methylation at all motif-adjacent</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2320" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2320"></td>
        <td id="LC2320" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">probes, and the $U$ group, which consisted of the 20<span class="pl-cce">\%</span>  of samples with the lowest </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2321" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2321"></td>
        <td id="LC2321" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">methylation. This step is performed by the get.TFs function, which takes <span class="pl-mi">*minSubgroupFrac*</span> as an input parameter, again with a default of 20<span class="pl-cce">\%</span>.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2322" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2322"></td>
        <td id="LC2322" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">For each candidate motif-TF pair, the Mann-Whitney U test is used to test </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2323" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2323"></td>
        <td id="LC2323" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">the null hypothesis that overall gene expression in group $M$ is greater or equal </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2324" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2324"></td>
        <td id="LC2324" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">than that in group $U$. This non-parametric test was used in order to minimize the </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2325" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2325"></td>
        <td id="LC2325" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">effects of expression outliers, which can occur across a very wide dynamic range. </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2326" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2326"></td>
        <td id="LC2326" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">For each motif tested, this results in a raw p-value ($P_r$) for each of the human TFs.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2327" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2327"></td>
        <td id="LC2327" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2328" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2328"></td>
        <td id="LC2328" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">All TFs are ranked by their $-log_{10}(Pr)$ values, and those falling within the top 5<span class="pl-cce">\%</span> of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2329" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2329"></td>
        <td id="LC2329" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">this ranking were considered candidate upstream regulators. The best upstream </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2330" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2330"></td>
        <td id="LC2330" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">TFs which are known to recognize to specific binding motif are automatically extracted as putative </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2331" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2331"></td>
        <td id="LC2331" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">regulatory TFs, and rank ordered plots are created to visually inspect these relationships, as shown in the example below. Because the same motif can be recognized by many transcription factors of the same binding domain family, we define these relationships at both the family and subfamily classification level using the </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2332" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2332"></td>
        <td id="LC2332" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">classifications from TFClass database [<span class="pl-v">@</span><span class="pl-s">wingender2013tfclass</span>]. </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2333" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2333"></td>
        <td id="LC2333" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L2334" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="2334"></td>
        <td id="LC2334" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">The Supervised  mode uses the same approach as described for the identification of putative target gene(s) step. The $U$ and $M$ groups are one of the the label group of samples and the <span class="pl-mi">*minSubgroupFrac*</span> parameter is set to 100<span class="pl-cce">\%</span> to use all samples from both groups in the statistical test. </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>

        <td id="LC2335" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
